abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Promoting Girls'
            Education in Balochistan Project for Pakistan were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            communities’ strong sense of ownership of schools
            contributed to enhancing girls’ education. Recruiting female
            teachers from the own community contributed to increased
            comfort among community members and developed a great role
            model for girls. A community-led model of needs
            identification provides a cost-effective solution to new
            school establishment, which can be adopted in similar,
            sparsely-populated places. In Balochistan, where low
            population density and sparse population is a constraint for
            service delivery, the PGEB tackled the problem by soliciting
            applications from communities and surveying communities to
            verify the actual needs of the set criteria. This approach
            enabled fast establishment of schools in communities, which
            have commitment and willingness to contribute to education,
            and increased access of children to school. Flexibility of
            project design toward achievement of objectives and quick
            decisions will ensure timely implementation and maximization
            of benefits. When it was found that there would be savings
            due to cancellation of some activities for security reasons,
            the PMU took an initiative to revise the procurement plan
            and the GoB made a quick decision to reallocate funds.
            Additional outputs, as listed in annex two, contributed to
            increase the beneficiaries and project outcomes by
            efficiently utilizing the available funds.
